Fields.DialogueText: Takao, do you think you're getting a little carried away with the landscaping? I mean, nice little ponds are one thing, but now you have an algae-filled bog in progress.
It may not have a pristine appearance to it, but it has its own surreal beauty.
Still, what are you going to put in it? I don't think it would work for goldfish; at least, not with the domestic kinds.
Ah, Kanchou, you have much to learn. Nature's children are bred to be determined warriors, and every environment shines with its own life.
Such as... wah!
Frogs, for one.
Takao, get them under control, at least. They're going to be tough to manage with their jumping abilities.
Still, they will make a nice touch for the environment.

Fields.MenuText: Well, just make sure they don't escape onto land.
I've always wondered what frog legs taste like.
They are kind of cute in their own way, I guess.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't worry. I'll keep a sharp watch on them.
I wouldn't know, but you are welcome to try after there is a stable population.
I know. Everything, from life to death, from youthful to aged, has its own special appeal. By embracing it all, you can truly start to understand the world.
I see you've also planted some more trees around the swamp.
Well, these ones were more for a symbolic effect. They're willow trees, you see, and there's a story about frogs and willows.
There is? What's it about?
A calligrapher had almost given up on his art when he saw a frog try again and again to jump onto a willow's leaf... until, on the eighth try, it succeeded.
I see. That story must be really inspiring to you, both as a calligraphist and as a warrior.
Exactly. No matter how many times we fall, we must pull ourselves up for one more try, again and again.
Well, let's prove that determination of ours against these Morganas. They don't stand a chance.
@BATTLE
In that case, you'd better catch the one that's hopping away right now.
Takao, there you are. I-- are you all right!?
Of course. Why do you ask?
Um... well, there's a basket over your head for one. Did it get stuck on you or something?
Oh, no, you need not worry. I am practicing the meditative art of the Komusō.
The Komusō?
Yes. They were a sect of monks who wore such baskets to enhance their meditation. By doing so, they could let go of their ego, as their appearance no longer mattered.
I see. Yet it would also require a deeper connection to the world as well, to sense where you were going.
You have a keen eye, my student. That is yet another reason why I wish to practice their method.
Still, doesn't it get kind of boring with nothing to see?
The eyes are but one of our senses. The mouth and the ears provide other wonders. Allow me to demonstrate. Listen while I play this melody on the flute.
That is neat. So did the Komusō also play the flute?
Yes, they did. What do you think of it?

Fields.MenuText: That was wonderful. You should try playing music more often.
It had a strange, determined tone to it. Almost like a warrior.
You seem to have mastered it already. Still, I like seeing your face as well.

Fields.DialogueText: You really think so? I do enjoy some forms of music, but they are traditional variants, so I don't know if many people would be interested.
Thank you. That was exactly what I was trying to convey. You see, the basket also offered a disguise for traveling warriors.
You do? Kanchou, can't you see you're making me blush? That's ridiculous for a samurai.
In any case, I'm glad you didn't have an accident or something. You are sure that you can get it off your head again, right?
Of course! How hard could it be?
That's good, because I see we have an enemy fleet heading our way.
Don't worry, I'll have this off in a... uh, oh.
Tougher than you thought?
I... think I could use a little help. And hurry, there's not a minute to lose!
@BATTLE
I know I would.
I wouldn't have known unless you told me.
Some days, Kanchou, I... never mind.
But I only spoke the truth.
Working on more calligraphy there?
Yes, I am just about finished with a kakemono -- a wall scroll. Do you want to see it?
Sure, let's see what it looks like.
All right, here it is.
Pretty nice. I like the decorative frames on the sides. But what does that written character in the middle mean?
It is Hinomaru, the "round of the sun." The title for our national flag.
I see. The sun is one of Japan's great symbols, so I can see why it would be auspicious.
In more ways than one. Maru, you see, was also used as a title for ships back in the Muromachi era.

Fields.MenuText: Well, thanks for telling me about that. You learn a new thing every day, they say.
Does that mean I should call you Takao-maru, then?
Why isn't it used nowadays?

Fields.DialogueText: That's one of the great things in life. You know... I'd like to learn some new things from you, now and then.
No, thank you. I do not like being called "round"; I pride myself on being an agile warrior, and too much roundness would just get in the way.
It's still common; maybe too much. Civilian vessels still use the term, but us warships use "kan" instead.
Well, you really did a great job with it.
Thank you. I think I am making significant strides forward in the art.
Maybe we can hang it at the helm, as badge of honor of sorts.
Great idea. But we'll need to hold off until we deal with these youkai.
@BATTLE
It would be my pleasure.
Sorry. I just thought it might be a way to highlight your dedication as a warrior.
... All right, maybe now and then.
Takao, what are you up to? I need you to keep an eye out; with this fog rolling in, we need everyone to stay alert.
Sorry, I was just trying to make a few preparations.
It looks like you're just poking holes into buckets. Are you trying to make more head-wear for Komusō meditation?
No, this is a preventative measure against the sea ghosts.
... Ghosts?
The funayūrei, to be precise. They surround ships and demand a bucket from the crew, which they use to sink the ship. With these trick barrels, they won't be able to sink us.

Fields.MenuText: I think you're sturdy enough to not worry about sinking in that manner.
Do you really think we will encounter them out here?
If you encounter some, try the strategy we use against the Morganas

Fields.DialogueText: Still, I like to be prepared for all potential scenarios.
This is the kind of weather that they are most active in. And with ships coming to life, who knows what else is out there?
You're right. There's no reason to be afraid of the monsters in the dark anymore when we can fight back in turn.
Still, I'd like you to keep a watch for us.
Don't worry. I'm just about finished.
Too late. I see something coming out of the mist, and it's not one of your funayūrei pals.
That makes things all the easier, then.
@BATTLE
I see that the frog pond is coming along well. Just make sure they don't get out of hand.
They're doing fine. Don't worry.
Actually, the frogs are kind of a relief. When you got the little water spots installed I was worried about a mosquito population forming, but the frogs should keep the pests at bay.
That's the beauty of nature. Everything can balance out with enough time.
Say, I was meaning to ask, but what is with the statue you have in the pond? It looks like a frog, but also kind of like a parrot and a human.
That's a kappa, another one of the more notable youkai.
Is its kind dangerous?
All youkai are in one way or another. But it also sometimes cooperates with humans and offers boons to farmers and fishermen.
I see. There are a lot of interesting monsters in Japanese lore.
Well, diversity is one of the key attributes of the natural world, after all, and the spiritual world is deeply tied with the environment.

Fields.MenuText: Out of curiosity, which do you think would win in a duel: a tengu or a kappa?
What kind of cuisine does it like?
Hopefully we can keep that vibrant ecology alive throughout the world.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm... not actually sure, to be honest. A tengu is more skilled in the martial arts, and would have the sky to command, but the kappa is unmatched in the water.
Cucumbers! Beings after my own heart.
Yes, that is a considerable challenge of late. Still, I hope that we can find ways to live harmoniously.
I hope that the new statue did not cost that much.
Don't worry, it fit into my budget all right.
Just try to make sure all your additions don't get damaged. A lot can happen in battle.
I will protect this little paradise to my last breath.
Then get ready. We have more Morganas on the way.
@BATTLE
I see. So they would be evenly matched.
Then again, they are both rather civilized youkai, so they might become friends instead. I wonder what sort of miraculous things they could accomplish together?
Yes, I can see that. Kind of a relief to know that it's a vegetarian, in any case.
Well, not quite...
You're certainly leading us in the right direction with your projects.
Good job. You've gotten much better as a fighter.
Thanks. Out of curiosity, though, when will I learn some of the fancy techniques you know?
That is for me to decide, and for you to be patient.
Please? I just want to know the time frame.
Well, the truth is that I'm not sure if I will teach you them.
Why? Do you think that I am not good enough?
No, it's quite the opposite. I want you to get stronger, and know you will. But I want it to be on your own terms.
I'm a little confused.
In truth, special techniques are a hindrance to true warriors. Certainly they have their own strengths, but follow them rigidly and you become complacent.
I see. So you want me to develop my own approach to it.
Exactly. I can prepare you as much as I can, but the final steps are up to you.
Easier said than done. I'm not exactly sure where to go with my techniques.
Nevertheless, I have faith you will figure something out.

Fields.MenuText: Can we at least talk about how to come up with techniques?
How about this? I'll teach you some new techniques once I come up with them, and then you can teach me yours.
I'll try my best, then.

Fields.DialogueText: I can give you a few insights, but the best ones come from within, as you apply your experiences to your approach.
That could work. I look forward to seeing what you have in store for me.
That is all I can ask. Go for it!
I'd better start thinking on it. Not sure when I'll come up with something.
Don't worry too much about it. Inspiration will come in its own time.
For now, let's use what skills we have to keep the Morganas at bay.
With enough training, we can eliminate them for good.
@BATTLE
Nice shot there, Takao!
Thanks! I always strike true and hard.
And with plenty of guns to bear, to boot.
The more the merrier, they say.
That is true. By the way, Takao, I wanted to ask you something.
Go ahead, take that! What is it?
Do you think you could also give me some firearms training?
You have come to the right place. I can teach you all you need to know.
Thank you. I appreciate it.
Still, what made you interested? It is good that you are expanding into gunplay, but I do not want you to neglect your current training either.

Fields.MenuText: I got inspired watching you out there.
With training for both the sword and the gun, I can handle enemies at both close and long range.
I want to be able to give you firing support if you need it.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you. But you should know that you have your own path before you.
An astute plan. A great warrior knows to be well-rounded in many things, as there is never one sole path to victory.
You do not need to worry about that. It will take more than a few Morganas to stop me. But... thanks for caring about me like that.
So, when do you want to get started with your additional training?
Probably after the battle. Won't be long, though.
Yes, we're almost done here. Let's keep at it until they're finished!
@BATTLE
I understand that. Nevertheless, I wish to learn and gain at least a degree of your finesse.
Takao, how are-- aaahh!
Sorry, Kanchou. The stubborn things have minds of their own.
What's with the bow and arrows?
I am an expert in modern forms of ranged combat, but I thought I might try my hand at the more traditional approach.
I can see that. I can also see that you need to work on your aim a little.
I'm still getting used to it. It's a little different than your usual gun.

Fields.MenuText: Just calm down and open your mind up a bit. You've mastered a gauntlet of different firearms, so you should be able to adapt to this in time.
Maybe you should apply some of your spiritual philosophy to handling it.
Take your time and concentrate on your aim. Safety is the first priority.

Fields.DialogueText: Good point. I just need to get used to the difference in weight and recoil.
You're right. I was getting so frustrated in my failures that I forgot the whole point of the exercise.
Right! I don't want anyone to get hurt.
Let me try again... I got it!
Bullseye! Great job, Takao!
Thank you. Still, I need to practice more so it is not a fluke.
It's significant improvement from your last one.
Sorry about that, by the way.
No problem. At least you didn't try a William Tell by shooting an apple off my head.
Hmm... A peach might be more appropriate, but...
Oh, no. Please leave me out of your idea, Takao.
Please? I just want to test my perfection of the art.
No thanks. If you'll excuse me, I'll attend to the Morganas -- I have a better chance of coming out with my head.
@BATTLE
Right this way, Takao. I have a little surprise for you.
What is it? And do I really have to wear the Komusō basket?
Yes. Otherwise you might see my surprise too soon.
I can still sense my surroundings, you know. And I can detect the condensation ahead. If you plan to play a jape on me, I can find ways to keep you more occupied with training.
Don't worry, I think that you'll like this surprise. And here we are!
Finally. Now... wait, what?
Surprised?
That's a...
A custom-made waterfall. Not quite as organic as you might like, but it was tricky getting enough force through the shower, and collecting the water so it doesn't flood the deck.
You really made this for me?

Fields.MenuText: I know that you have a little difficulty with engineering, so I thought that I could help you with bringing your idea to life.
Just consider it a thanks for all the help you've given me.
You've helped me become stronger, but I want to help you become stronger too.

Fields.DialogueText: Thanks. I don't like admitting my weaknesses, but I'm really happy that you helped me move forward with it.
Still, you didn't need to go this far.
Thank you... you're really something, Kanchou.
In any case, enjoy!
I will. Let's get ready for some suigyo practice!
Wait, "let's"?
Of course. After all the effort you put into this, I can hardly leave you out, can I?
Still, I'm not quite sure about this...
One other thing you need to work on is your honesty; don't think I missed that you've already changed into appropriate attire.
Well, it sounded kind of interesting.
Then what are we waiting for? ... Wait, we might have to postpone; that roaring isn't just from the waterfall.
@BATTLE
No, I did not. But I did anyways.
There! That should do it.
Hanging up another wall scroll? I see that you did some painting this time.
I've been trying to expand my artistry, and this was the best way for what I had in mind.
It looks great. Though, what is with the two different mountains, and their identical labels underneath them?
They are both named Takao.
Oh, you mean Mount Takao. Interesting. Are they supposed to be different views of the mountain?
No; rather, they are different views of the mountains.
But I thought that both of them were of Mount Takao?
Yes, but there is more than one Takao for my namesake.
You mean there's another one besides the one outside Tokyo?
Yes, the other is in Kyoto.

Fields.MenuText: I like how you arranged them together like this.
Which one is which, out of curiosity?
Funny; before you told me, I was noticing ways that the two were similar. Even if they are in different places, both of them clearly embody your strength.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you. I wanted to illustrate that they are equally important in my life, and that this ship will represent both of them.
The top one is Kyoto's, as that is the one I am officially named after, and the lower one is Hachioji's.
You're right. They are both a part of my story, and together they make me into who I am.
So, where do you want to hang it?
I was thinking along one of the masts.
You might want to store it indoors. You don't want this lovely thing to get damaged in a battle.
Good point. Speaking of which, my senses picked something up. Want to check it out?
@BATTLE
Takao, I wanted to talk to you about your little forest on board.
What about it? I've made sure to keep it within reasonable bounds, and there hasn't been a timber accident for weeks.
Yes, but there's another issue. A number of sea birds have decided that the trees make comfortable, mobile roosts to use between catches.
That's neat. I didn't realize that. So what is the problem, then?
Takao, that is the problem. The birds make a racket, they're aggressive about defending their "territory", and most of all they poop!
Well, that is a biological necessity.
Let me be more specific. They're interfering with the integrity of the mission.
I'm sorry, Kanchou. But could you please give them a little slack? They can't help it, you know.
I know, but do they have to nest here? They can find other places to rest at sea, right?
I know, but it makes me really happy that they decided to call this mountain home. It almost seems like the tengu have come.

Fields.MenuText: I suppose what's done is done. They can stay.
This place is becoming not just a nature park -- it's becoming a zoo.
The birds are kind of interesting, I admit.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you. This means a lot to me.
Is that necessarily a bad thing?
My thoughts exactly. Perhaps some of them are new species of youkai, and we just don't know it.
Oh, all right. But we need to start putting up warning signs about the hazards.
All right, I understand. Wait, why are you birdies flying away now?
Most likely because they instinctively recognize a predator, even a metal one. Everyone get ready -- here they come!
@BATTLE
Just as long as they behave themselves and don't try to eat us.
At it again, huh? I see that you're working on the spear again.
It is a rather versatile weapon, and it really deserves more respect these days.
Well, I certainly respect your wielding of it. You thrust it like a master.
Thank you. Even so, I am always trying to get better.
I'm sure that you will.
I know, but sometimes it feels like I have already reached the pinnacle. What then?

Fields.MenuText: What if you taught me? It might give you some new insights.
Have you considered throwing them as projectiles?
In any case, you are quite graceful with it.

Fields.DialogueText: And give you an excuse to learn, I see.
That would be interesting. I don't know, though. Unlike bullets, every spear has its own grandeur, and it feels like a waste to throw them away.
Thank you. The womanly grace of the art is part of what appeals to me in the spear, as it gives me a sense of serenity midst conflict.
Well, keep up the good work.
I will. One day, I will try to match the prowess of Kiyomasa himself.
You'd better put them away for now, though. Those Morganas look like they want to kebab us.
@BATTLE
...That, too.
Still, it is food for thought. I may try some exercises with you later.
Good point, especially out here. Still, you could practice a little on board.
Let's see you handle this!
Heh, I've got this now!
Good job. You managed to disarm me.
I just got lucky.
Nevertheless, it is time for the next step of your tutelage. Here.
This is... a real sword. You want me to practice with one of these now?
More than practice. It is yours.
Wait, you're actually giving it to me?
Yes. You have earned the right to truly called yourself a sword fighter. The road ahead is still long, but you must now stand tall with your pride and honor as a samurai.

Fields.MenuText: I don't know. I could seriously hurt someone or myself with this.
Thank you. I promise to take good care of it.
I am honored, sensei.

Fields.DialogueText: That is the price of all warfare. Nevertheless, there is grace in such a path. Just always remember the life and death you hold in your hands.
Treasure it well. A sword is the truest companion of a samurai, the one you can depend on the most.
You more than earned it. But this privilege requires continual diligence, so I will not hold back in our spars.
Thank you again. I wish I could repay you.
Simply show me your strength as a hero in today's engagement and beyond. In this age of falling darkness, we cannot hesitate for even a second.
I won't. The Morganas must be stopped, and I will fight to the last.
@BATTLE
Didn't you call yourself a sword once?
I did. And I am honored to be your sword in battle.
I would expect nothing less.
What's with the boat model you have there? Is it some ancient warship from Japanese history?
Not exactly. The vessel is the Takarabune, the transport of the Seven Lucky Gods.
The Seven Lucky Gods?
Seven deities who crossed the sea to Japan and decided to call it home.
I see. So this is a good luck charm.
Exactly. If you have such a symbol under your pillow, you will have especially fortunate dreams.

Fields.MenuText: Wouldn't the toy get crushed in the process?
What counts as a lucky dream, out of curiosity?
I wonder what that dream boat is right now.

Fields.DialogueText: I paraphrased a bit. Generally people use a picture for the pillow.
That is an interesting topic. They say that Mount Fuji or a hawk are good dreams, but I would like an intense battle that gets my blood going.
Who knows? They dock on New Year's Eve, but they could be anywhere right now.
You know, what you said about the Takarabune reminds me of us.
Us?
Yes. We are all out here on a long journey, trying to bring luck and hope to the world.
That is a compelling way to look at it. Back then, a trip across the sea, just from China to Japan, was an incredible odyssey. And now we face an even greater challenge.
Still, we'll overcome them again and again. We have kami of our own on our side, after all.
You're right. Let's start by destroying these ill omens and giving the world a better chance at holding on.
@BATTLE
Ah, that makes sense. Still, this is bound to give us good luck.
Whereas that would be a nightmare for me. I guess good luck depends on the eye of the beholder.
Maybe we'll get lucky and find them. Some divine help would be welcome against the Morganas.
Kanchou, what are you doing out here? You should be inside with all this rain coming down.
No choice in the matter. I need to make sure everyone's keeping watch, and I have some inspections to carry out.
Can't it wait? The storm is really bad right now.
Weren't you the one to suggest purification under water? I'll be fine.
Come on. We can play a game or something inside. I'm just worried about you.

Fields.MenuText: Why are you worried all of a sudden?
I can take this. If I want to be as strong as you one day, I have to push myself to the limit.
It's just... you're always exposed to the rain out here. I didn't want you to be alone.

Fields.DialogueText: Because I care about you, dummy! You're my... apprentice, so I have to look after you.
There's a breaking point, you know. But I admire your will to become the strongest.
Kanchou, some days... I don't know what to think of you.
I guess it can't be helped. Wait here a moment.
What's this?
It's a traditional mino, made from various grasses I've grown on board. Take it and you won't have to worry about the rain so much.
... Thank you.
No need to thank me. I just don't want to have to nurse you back to full strength.
Looks like the thunder is getting worse.
No, that's something else. Figures they would turn up in this weather.
@BATTLE
Go, go Yamato!
You seem especially chipper today.
I just want to be able to cheer on Yamato with all my might.
Yeah, she really is a strong fighter in this war.
I know, right. So dashing, so noble, such a perfect symbol of the samurai.
Huh, it sounds like you really like her.
I sure do! Hey, what's with that glum face?
No reason. I'm happy for you... I mean, it's nice to see you look up to her.
Still, you look kind of upset. Are you jealous of her or something?

Fields.MenuText: And what if I am?
No, I just feel disappointed that I can't be as strong as her.
Sorry, but I don't want to talk about it.

Fields.DialogueText: It's all right to be jealous. I am jealous of her skills at times as well.
Don't be. You will never be her, and neither will I. We all have our own strengths to bring to battle. I just want to prove that I can at least match her in determination.
All right, I understand. But you can share things with me, you know? We're friends, after all.
Look, Kanchou, you don't need to worry about Yamato. I mostly have a fan crush on her. She is my hero, but that is sometimes different from a lover.
Who said anything about love?!
Nobody, of course. Anyway, I see a Morgana fleet on the move. Let's show Yamato that we have just as much samurai spirit in us. Coming?
I'm right behind you, always.
@BATTLE
That's not quite what I meant...
Me too.
Yeah, friends...
Takao, what are you doing in here? I thought we had an agreement about your renovations: it's fine to refurbish the exterior areas, but the inside's to be left alone.
Sorry, but this was one thing that I could not leave aside.
And what is that? The sailors like having at least the interior normal, so whatever you're doing, stop it, please.
But...
All right, what is it?
It's a bathhouse.
A bathhouse?
Yes, a complete one, with all of the stations for proper cleaning before and after. See, here's the blueprint.
Wow, you put a lot of thought into this. Were you planning to do this all on your own?
I just thought it would be a nice way for everyone to relax after a long day.

Fields.MenuText: I'm sorry, Takao. I overreacted.
In that case, let me help out. Just tell me what to do, and we'll have this bath up and running in no time.
I would have been fine with this at the start if you had just told me. Even so, I'm sorry for getting so worked up.

Fields.DialogueText: I forgive you. Some of my ideas have been a little wild, I admit. But I really mean well with them!
You will? Thank you!
I know. I was just nervous you would say no.
I am a little surprised that you weren't content with the pools up on deck.
I enjoy nature, of course, but cleanliness is also essential for a healthy soldier.
I'm interested to see what it will be like when it's finished. Look, I...
You don't need to apologize. I'm just glad we worked it out and are still friends.
... Friends. Of course.
Uh-oh. I think we need to get above deck now. I've picked up some ominous activity up ahead.
@BATTLE
I know. Actually, it's one of the things I lo-- like about you.
No problem.
I admit that I have been a little hard on your ideas at times. I'll try to work on it.
Fishing again?
It's a nice way to pass the time every now and then.
I suppose. On the other hand, it is a sign that you clearly have nothing else to do.
That's what I thought. Not much is going on right now, so the time is perfect for this.
That's funny, because I somehow thought we were going to go through some katas around now.
Oh, yeah...
So? Are we going to get started, or do I need to apply some discipline?

Fields.MenuText: This is a sort of meditative exercise on its own. You need to be patient as you wait for a bite.
Look, just as you have pride as a warrior, I take pride as a fisher, as I take on incredible challenges.
We both have our own little hobbies and things we enjoy. Can I please have it this time?

Fields.DialogueText: Hmm... It seems somewhat of an excuse to cover up your lack of success in catching anything.
You're exaggerating, but I admire your guts. Very well. Do your best; and me proud as your teacher as you take on the creatures of the deep.
All right, I understand.
Fine, you can do that! I just wanted to have fun training with you again.
Well... I didn't say that you had to be left out, Takao.
What do you mean?
Well, if you just want to spend time together with me, I welcome the company.
Are you sure? I never really learned how to fish, so I would just get in the way.
Actually, even though I want to fish, I also wanted to spend the day with you. So, want to try your hand at catching something?
Sure. I just hope that I don't catch a giant earthquake catfish.
Ha, that's unlikely...
*BOOM*
Um... is it too late to say that I was joking, gods?
Good news and bad news, Takao. Good news: no catfish. Bad news: Morganas.
@BATTLE
Hey!
I'm not actually going to fight them, you know.
You sure? I hear that halibuts are particularly stubborn. You could wrestle him if you really want to boast about your might as a fisher.
Now, when would be the right time to plant them? I need to account for delivery time as well...
What are you working on?
Oh, I'm figuring out how to bring in some new trees for the garden. See, I have a picture here.
I see. That bright pink is a cherry tree, right?
Yes, a sakura. The difficulty is how to arrange the timing just right. The flowers blossom for only a few days, and I want the first impression on board to be auspicious.
That makes sense. Though I wonder why the tree is so important in Japan when its flowers only last a few days.
They may last for but a few moments, but the beauty more than makes up for it. And there is the spiritual aspect to it as well.
What do you mean?
There's the saying that just as the sakura is the king and queen of flowers, a samurai is a king and queen among men and women, living for but a few brief moments of glory.
That's... actually kind of unsettling.
It is simply the way of the world. Everything in the end crumbles and dies. Even a sakura flower that returns from the grave of winter may once again perish for good.
Takao...
So why be so gloomy about the end? What really matters is appreciating the life that exists now, in the moment. Even if death comes, the beauty endures in memory.

Fields.MenuText: But I don't want to lose you, Takao.
I guess that's one way to always look on the bright side.
Let's make the most of the time we have left, then.

Fields.DialogueText: And I don't want to lose you either, or my sisters. But we have to accept what comes, and keep moving forward to our destinies. Don't worry. I'll be beside you until the end.
Yep. Always look on the bright side of life and death, I say.
Exactly. There's so much to see in this world, so we may as well enjoy it while we can.
I can't say I like this morbid outlook, or your fatalistic dedication to your duty. But I have to say, Takao, you're one of the bravest people I know.
You as well, Kanchou.
*ALARM*
One more challenge. I wonder if this will be the last straw for us?
If it is, we will go out with a bang. Time to get started. For the Emperor and the throne!
@BATTLE
Hey, look! There's a big whale over there!
Amazing. They're such beautiful creatures.
Do you think we have to worry about a Moby Dick incident?
Don't worry. Whales are normally peaceful beings. Best for us to just leave it in peace.
That's what I was thinking as well. It's a little surprising to hear you say that, though. I thought Japan was big on whaling.
Many people are, but I am not. I... just do not think it is right to kill them.
I have many reasons for that. My love for nature, my spiritual honor, my sense of morality... I could go on and on.

Fields.MenuText: I see. You really care about the natural world, don't you?
What is the spiritual side of it?
Yeah, you're a vegetarian, aren't you? It's sometimes surprising since you are so vicious in battle.

Fields.DialogueText: I do. It can be so beautiful at times. Which is why I want to cry when it is tarnished. All life fades, but forcing it before its time is a tragedy.
The spirits of whales, great wanderers of the seas, endure as ghosts, the bakekujira. Best not to disturb them and draw their wrathful curses.
I have my responsibilities as a soldier, but outside of the battlefield I try to respect all living things.
There they go. They seem to be in a big hurry now. I wonder why?
Well, there's an even bigger one behind them, coming right out of the mist. Just look at it.
Um, I don't think that is a whale, Takao.
This is one species I do not mind hunting down.
There she blows. Duck, everyone!
@BATTLE
Huff... these Morganas aren't making it easy for us this time.
They're hardened warriors at this point. Would you expect anything different?
No... but I sure would like to be able to, these days. Nuts, how are we going to get out of this one?
What, panicking now? You need to stay strong, Kanchou. They haven't finished us yet.
You're right. We have to keep fighting.
Still, something needs to change. You have a plan?
Don't worry. One just came to me.
Good. I don't like to get discouraged, but we're in a tough spot right now.

Fields.MenuText: Help extract some of our comrades from danger over there. They can't hold out much longer.
Target your fire on the escort in front of us. If we can just get them out of the way, things should go smoothly.
We're going to have to pull back for the moment to regroup. Then we'll be back for round two.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't worry! I'll get them out on the double!
You've got it. I'll make sure they stay down for good.
I understand. I don't like it, but sometimes we have to make tough decisions.
There! Your plan is working. Ready for one last go?
You bet! Time to teach them not to mess with samurai and sailors!
@BATTLE
But don't drop your weapons in the process, all right?
Things are looking gloomy on the horizon, Kanchou. That ship does not look like one of ours.
@BATTLE
Well, that's that!
Now that we are finished, shall we celebrate with tea?
That sounds good. But I wanted to ask you something.
What is it?
Well, I know that you are already teaching me a lot of things, but I was wondering... Could you please teach me the art of tea?
Are you certain? It will not be easy to master the craft.
If I recall correctly, you've said that same line in regard to my other training, and look at how far I have come.
A valid point. Nevertheless, it takes dedication to progress in the art. Therefore, I must know your reason for asking.

Fields.MenuText: Because it's a way for us and others to come together and bond.
I want to understand the secrets behind it.
You seem so graceful when you manage the ceremony. I just want to see if I can attain that sense of artistic solemnity as well.

Fields.DialogueText: That is kind of a silly answer... but also a nice one. You have a lot of compassion, Kanchou.
You will never know all the intricacies; I know I still do not. Still, your desire to learn more is a good first step toward enlightenment.
You really see me as graceful? I'm always tripping over myself.
I suppose I have no choice then. I will instruct you to the best of my abilities.
Thank you, teacher.
The first thing to understand is that the tea ceremony is more than an art. It is a philosophy, a way of finding harmony in the world.
I still don't fully understand, but I will try to.
That is all you need to move forward.
You can be a little clumsy at times. But whether as a warrior or as a teacher, you always have this beautiful grace to you.
Kanchou...
The key to understanding the philosophy I am teaching, whether through battle or tea, is that everything begins with the void. With nothing existing at all.
Isn't that kind of morbid?
You're looking at it the wrong way, Kanchou. Rather than seeing the emptiness, you should be focusing on the potential.
I think I see. A vacuum means that there is space for life to develop.
Exactly. Moreover, it means that everything, by filling the emptiness of the world, has its own value.
That's why you care so much about nature, isn't it? Because it is all precious to you, like everything.
Yes. From my weapons to a small flower or bug, everything fulfills a role in the world. By accepting this and recognizing the beauty inside them, we can grow stronger.
So what is the next step for me?
Let us do some meditation to embrace the world's deeper plane.
How was that?

Fields.MenuText: You didn't hit me this time.
I felt like I was at peace for the moment.
It took a lot of weight off my chest.

Fields.DialogueText: I did not have to. Unless you wanted me to.
Hold onto those moments as long as you can, no matter what happens.
I know. Leaving aside philosophy, there is something therapeutic about meditating.
I think we have gotten far enough in our lesson today. I still need to test your fighting abilities.
I think we might have an alternative test coming our way.
I see. They won't be able to stand against us. Ready, Kanchou?
You bet. I feel more ready than ever.
@BATTLE
I had just gotten used to it, that's all.
All right, Takao. Ready for our next practice match?
In a moment. I wanted to give you something first.
You don't need to do that.
But you have done so much, and I... anyway, this gift is essential for your training.
Let me see. Gloves?
Kote, specially-made covers for your hands. The hand is the most vulnerable yet critical part of any warrior, so it will make me feel better if you wear them.
Huh, they fit me like a glove. I'm amazed that you managed to find a pair that works this well.
I didn't. That's why I decided to custom make one.
You did? I thought you were still struggling with sewing.
I am, but I persevered.

Fields.MenuText: Please be careful. I don't want your hands to get hurt either.
Thank you. This is a wonderful gift.
You did a great job with it.

Fields.DialogueText: You're too kind, Kanchou.
You're welcome. I'm just happy that you like it.
Of course. I did not want you to be impeded by a poor quality kote.
Anyway, thank you again for the present.
Don't mention it. Now, then, time to see how you have progressed with the sword.
I think we're going to have to hold off on that. It looks like I'm going to test out my gloves with some real action.
@BATTLE
Takao! Takao, are you all right?
@BATTLE
Thank you for helping me back there. This was a tough battle.
Yes, but now we can relax for a little bit. Do you want to do another tea ceremony now?
Actually... there's something else I want to talk to you about.
Oh? What is it? Another nature project, or something with training?
No, it's about... I can't say it.
Say what? You know that I'm always willing to listen.
We have bonded a lot through our shared hardships and joys in this war.
Yes, we have. It's been always a pleasure to fight and learn alongside you.
The same goes for you. But, anyway, what I mean is... here, I have some calligraphy for you. With a translation just to be safe.
Let's see. "My heart burns on the battlefield and quiets in the garden. But what is it that stirs it with the hope of the sky?" It's beautiful. It's lovely, just like you.
Sometimes you are too thick-headed, Kanchou.
What do you mean?
What I mean is... I love you.
What?
You are so eager to learn, and so determined. I want to help that spirit grow, but more than that, I want to connect with that beautiful heart.
Takao...
I know that it is shameful that I have kept this secret, and that it is unbecoming of my role as your sensei. I will accept whatever punishment you deem necessary.
Let's see. After careful thought, my punishment is that we go on a date.
You mean... you are all right with it?
To be honest, I can't get enough of your determination either.
Then... may you never see the end of it!
